repnme.cdata!: Burkina Faso - HIV/AIDS Disaster Response Project

abstracts.cdata!:
This is the Implementation Completion
            Report for the Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV)/Acquired
            Immuno-Deficiency Syndrome (AIDS) Disaster Response Project
            in Burkina Faso. The overall outcome of the project is rated
            as moderately unsatisfactory; the performance of the Bank
            was rated as moderately unsatisfactory; and the performance
            of the borrower was rated as moderately satisfactory.
            Lessons learned: set up a mechanism fostering associative
            action by the structures in a given place; introduce
            mechanisms and/or arrangements for closing the financial
            year to prevent breaks by the budget estimate for the
            activities of the first quarter of year Y+1 in the Year Y
            allocation; take up the option of a strategy for target
            groups at risk (gold panners and commercial sex workers)
            throughout all the country's regions; and include
            decentralized resource management mechanisms in the
            procedural manuals.

repnme.cdata!:
Burkina Faso - HIV/AIDS Disaster Response
            Project : environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
This environmental assessment for the
            HIV/AIDS Disaster Prevention Project for Burkina Faso
            elaborates a pertinent system of health care waste planning
            and management whose implementation will allow improved
            public health. This report recommends the following
            treatment and elimination systems: modern incinerators
            appropriate for national hospitals; the one-combustion room
            incinerator, a home-made incinerator appropriate for urban
            areas; and stabilized and side and bottom pits for Centers
            for Health and Social Promotion (CSPS) in rural areas,
            community health centers, and isolated maternities. To
            prevent inappropriate incinerators or non-combustibles
            (plastic, chemical, and radioactive products, mercury, heavy
            metals, etc.) from polluting the air, and to spreading the
            risk of contamination from infectious waste, the model of
            incinerator recommended will be based on waste segregation
            at the source. All types of waste will not be incinerated.
            Selective sifting will help send all non-contaminated waste
            towards more classical treating systems (disinfection,
            burial, garbage dumps) and only incinerate contaminated or
            risk-based wastes (needles, etc.). These categories of waste
            do not emit (or very likely do not emit) targeted toxic
            products, especially dioxins and mercury. Moreover, the
            system allows total melting of needles, which are the most
            feared vectors for accidental transmission of HIV/AIDS. The
            report recommends encapsulation, chemical disinfection, and
            storage in empty containers (bottles). In all cases,
            reusable instruments must be sterilized. In health centers
            located in provincial and rural areas, segregating waste
            will reduce the volume of waste significantly. Also, using
            non-chlorinated plastic containers should reduce pollution
            caused by incineration. Public landfills will receive
            treatment refuse (ashes from incineration, etc.). for liquid
            wastes, chemical disinfection will be used to treat
            infectious waste. A combined waste system (disinfecting and
            septic tank) will be employed for provincial and rural
            areas, and it is preferable apply physical-chemical
            treatment to hospital waste.

repnme.cdata!: Burkina Faso - HIV/AIDS Disaster Response Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The HIV/AIDS Disaster Response Project,
            an integral part of the Multi-Country AIDS Program for
            Africa, aims to assist the Government of Burkina Faso,
            implement the 2001-05 HIV/AIDS strategic plan, and mitigate
            the impacts of the epidemic. The main components include: 1)
            preparation, and implementation of annual HIV/AIDS work
            programs, which will fund preventive interventions, policy
            development, psycho-social counseling activities, and
            capacity building; 2) provincial activities, and community
            subprojects, will assist in the planning, and coordination
            of HIV/AIDS activities, screen, and monitor community
            subprojects, and, build capacities of communities, and
            associations for the implementation of subprojects.
            Community subprojects will be financed to include awareness,
            and education promotion on preventive practices; home-based
            care for those affected by the disease; care of orphans,
            and, income-generating activities to assist, and empower
            affected families economically. Technical support, and
            training to build capacities will be provided; 3) targeted
            interventions to curb the epidemic, through specialized
            expertise, selected based on an eligibility criteria as
            specified in the Implementation Manual. Activities will
            include preventive interventions, treatment, and care of
            sexually transmitted diseases, and HIV testing, and
            counseling; and, 4) project management, and monitoring and evaluation.
